I don't make many comments, but I feel inspired to make one after watching 
most of this video, that is posted on You Tube (going out of my way to not 
call it a documentary).

In the interest of full disclosure (which isn't really necessary on a 
comment to a video I suppose, but anyway...), I am a MM fan. I've watched 
the documentaries, and I've moderately dug into the references, and I am 
satisfied thus far that me is basically on the level. And while on this 
site, I kept seeing this on the recommended videos, but hadn't watched it 
yet, because I like Michael Moore, and was a little afraid to see what this 
video might say. But then I decided that I needed to see all of the 
material, good and bad, and make my own decision. After all, if there's 
evidence that will help me better understand someone, I should watch it. 
And if it says things I don't want to hear, but are true, then I'll change 
my views and opinions.

So....here goes. I checked into the people shown in this video, and their 
backgrounds, and if possible, what, in particular, they had to say. Also, I 
used my critical thinking to judge every little thing about this video, as 
I would with anything I watch (Michael Moore included). And I determined 
that this video is horse_shit (my apologies to horses). This is clearly an 
attempt to bring down Michael Moore. It was made in such a way to try to 
fool his fans, in particular, into thinking this is actually legitimate and 
fair. In other words, it's meant to make people think "they tried to give 
him the benefit of the doubt, but the evidence just was against him....he's 
a bad person". But anyone with a well-functioning brain will see thru this 
in short order. 

So if you're a Moore fan, definitely watch it, but it won't take long to 
see what I'm talking about. This is very deceptive...using the same 
techniques of propaganda that they accuse Moore of using. It is more clever 
in its deception than other videos I have seen, but nonetheless it is 
horse_shit (sorry again, horses!). My respect for Moore is still in tact. 
And the truth about this video underscores the very type of "evil" that he 
(Moore) is devoted to bringing into the light of day.﻿

A mere look at the ratings for this documentary should be some indicator of 
what a polarizing figure Michael Moore is.

I remember the first time I encountered his work.  It was "The Awful 
Truth", being aired on Australia's "Special Broadcasting Service" (SBS).  
Coming from a country where "stunt politics" were often coming from 
genuinely good politicians (yes, we actually do have a few left in our 
nation), particularly those who ran as 3rd parties or independents, I had 
no problem with the type of "stunt pseudo-politics" that he used in his 
show.  In fact, I was an avid fan.

Over time it became apparent that rather than letting the facts and 
evidence speak for themselves, that his work was littered with examples of 
misrepresentations and edit-room manipulations that ensured that his films 
would conform to his preconceived notion of how the finished product should 
all play out.

He may be a great filmmaker (and again, I have no problems with stunts, per 
se), but Michael Moore certainly has issues with journalistic integrity.  
To truth-seekers everywhere, this should be a huge red-flag.

Is it a matter of ego?  Controlled opposition? - These are things I don't 
have an answer for.  Still, those who support him and his work 
unquestioningly are doing themselves and their fellow citizens a great 
disservice.

One can respect a person for bringing certain issues to light...but that 
does not mean their work or journalistic integrity is beyond reproach...and 
Michael Moore certainly fits that category.

Now more than ever, truth-seekers need to be aware of deceptions coming 
from people who claim to be on their side.  If one aligns themselves with 
someone who is later shown to be deceptive, it will ultimately be highly 
detrimental to the cause of truth-seekers everywhere.

I'm not here to spark a political debate or further polarize Michael 
Moore...but there are certain realities we must all face: The man we 
thought was bringing us "The (whole) Awful Truth", has not been...and to 
bury our heads in the sand because we once supported his work is not the 
way that genuine truth-seekers should operate.﻿

despite progressively stricter gun laws, has not changed since 1987. Nor 
have the laws altered their lethality. In 2010, a British man with a double 
barreled shotgun killed 12 people in 3 hours. In 1987, another British mass 
shooter killed 16 people in 5 hours with semi-auto rifles.﻿

+Hotshotter3000  The rate did NOT "rise for many years afterward". I gave 
you the link proving that.  You are just making bullshit up now.

I invite you to read the following:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_firearm-related_death_rate

and then kindly shut the fuck up

+Joe Smith The rate actually rose for many years afterward, and it didn't 
start to drop until a few years ago. It only matched 1997 again in 2013, so 
basically for 16 the rate was higher AFTER the gun ban made. The rise began 
only after the gun laws were enact. There is zero evidence that the laws 
made a single dent.

The United States, on the other hand, has been having nothing but drops 
since 1997. If the US had similar trends as Britain, there would be at 
least 6000 additional deaths if they approached the problems similarly. 
Hardly an improvement. It is delusional to think the gun laws were 
effective.

Britain still has one of the highest crime rates in the developed world.

+Hotshotter3000 I know what you said. Britain has had so few mass shootings 
anyway, that to say the rate hasn't changed since 1987 is disingenuous, if 
not meaningless. Overall deaths and injuries from guns is down, even with 
1996 and 2010 factored in.

+Joe Smith I said mass shootings. Britain has been having them are somewhat 
regulate intervals now. 1987, then 1996, and now 2010. No change in 
lethality. People thought they would never have one after Dunblane, but 
they had one that was almost a carbon copy of Hungerford.

+Hotshotter3000 Yup. I'll pick just one statement for now: "The rate of 
mass shootings in Britain, despite progressively stricter gun laws, has not 
changed since 1987."

When starting with a baseline of extremely few mass shootings in Britain to 
begin with it's easy to claim no change. But there has been some change, in 
a downward trend. Overall gun deaths and injuries have fallen in Britain in 
the last 20 years, to a record low in fact:
 
http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/britain-records-18-fall-in-gun-deaths-1232069.html
+Joe Smith Because that's the perfect argument, isn't it?
Every word you wrote is completely utterly false.

Everyone should acknowledge that he brings awareness to many issues in 
America.  Whether or not you agree with his politics.﻿

snippet.textDisplay: Those are your BEST arguments against Michael Moore?﻿

Coming from a combat vet myself... I wish this fat POS would stop wearing 
my alma mater's hat. He gives Michigan State a bad name.﻿

In the summer of 2000, the Project for the New American Century (PNAC), a 
neo-conservative think tank riddled with soon to be Bush administration 
officials and advisers, issued a document calling for the radical 
restructuring of U.S. government and military policies. It advocated the 
massive expansion of defense spending, the re-invasion of Iraq, the 
military and economic securing of Afghanistan and Central Asia, increased 
centralized power and funds for the CIA, FBI, and NSA, among a slew of 
other policies that would, in the near future, be enacted upon their 
ascension to power. In the same document, they cite a potential problem 
with their plan. Referring to the goals of transforming the U.S. and global 
power structure, the paper states that because of the American public's 
slant toward ideas of democracy and freedom, "this process of 
transformation is likely to be a long one, absent some catastrophic and 
catalyzing event - like a new Pearl Harbor."﻿

more from a foreigner getting a job there over a German. All nations should

Oh and their beer....Bless you for your beer.

Thankfully I never bought any of his shit because I've, almost from the

Most notable of which, and this video reminded me of it, was the one where

cemented my view this was all just showmanship to make himself look good,

Oy. Clearly doesn't know ANYTHING about Bowling For Columbine. Or Canada's

Just getting started, but so far I'm seeing a whole lot of "fill."﻿
